Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Automated observations of phytoplankton communities from open water moorings
Award.AbstractNarration:
Phytoplankton are a diverse group of microscopic organism living near the ocean surface. They play essential role in marine food webs and global biogeochemical cycles. The Imaging FlowCytobot(IFCB) has been used for a number of years but because of the high power requirements deployment has been limited to these types of nearshore sites with power and internet connection. This EAGER proposal will test deploy the Imaging FlowCytobot on an open ocean mooring.

The ability to determine the composition and temporal dynamics of phytoplankton communities is important but traditional methods for collecting samples is time consuming. The Imaging FlowCytobot (IFCB) was developed at WHOI as a submersible flow cytometer that can resolve particles in the 10-150 micrometer size range, including critical phytoplankton groups such as diatoms, dinoflagellates, and coccolithophores, and can capture up to 30,000 high resolution images per hour. To date IFCB?s have been deployed at coastal fixed structures (piers, tower) with power, internet, and regular maintenance. This EAGER proposal will expand the operational capabilities of IFCB by testing it on an open ocean mooring. If successful, a new generation of autonomous plankton samplers could be deployed in geographically diverse locations throughout the global ocean in ecologically and biogeochemically significant locations far from the coastlines. This project will fund a graduate student from SIO who will be trained to operate and maintain the IFCB, as well as analyze data using machine learning tools and image analysis software.

Institution.Name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plankton communities in the remote ocean are difficult and costly to observe. Here we have developed the capability to deploy an Imaging FlowCytobot, or IFCB, on an uncabled mooring away from shore-based power and internet using solar power and mobile data connectivity. The IFCB is capable of taking high quality images of particles in the water in the 10-150 micron size range, including important groups of phytoplankton and zooplankton such as diatoms, dinoflagellates, and cilliates. Over the duration of the award, we deployed an IFCB at the Del Mar mooring, approximately 5km offshore of La Jolla, CA, in three successive deployments, each longer than the last. The final deployment in spring 2020 lasted nearly six months, during which time the IFCB took multiple samples per day on the mooring, and observed a harmful algal bloom by the dinoflagellate Lingulodinium polyedra.

Over the three deployments, we developed the technology and system for powering, controlling, and accessing data from the IFCB while deployed at sea. The IFCB was powered by solar panels on a surface mooring, and could be shut on and off remotely to save power. Image data were transferred via the cellular network to data servers on shore. The status of the instrument could be remotely monitored, and sampling frequency adjusted to meet the power supplied by the solar panels. We were able to test the IFCB using a newer Linux version of the control software, and tested new functionality for subsampling the data volume sent to shore, in preparation for future remote ocean deployments that will likely have lower data connectivity.

Using the images collected by the IFCB at the Del Mar mooring, we applied two analysis pathways. The first quantified the morphometrics of imaged particles, including volume and cross sectional area. The second used machine learning tools to classify each image into predefined categories, such as important species in the regions (e.g., Lingulodinium polyedra) and noise categories (e.g., bubble). From these analyses, we were able to observe over six months a bloom of Lingulodinium polyedra from January to June of 2020. The bloom was likely caused by a confluence of abundant subsurface nutrients, surface stratification, and warmer than normal ocean temperatures.

Collectively the work help paves the way for future deployments of the IFCB in the remote ocean.
